content: How do we utilize t⋅t=tt\cdot t=tt⋅t=t to obtain a factorization τ\tauτ of ttt throguh ddd ? Snímek-obrazovky-2023-10-31-212130.png
I think there is an error in the question, please could you edit it?
Thank you for noticing my question. Could you specify that error for me ?
I mean grammatically, rather than mathematically, it doesn't currently make sense.
My English is poor, but I have done my best to make it clear. What's wrong with it ?

It looks like we have two categories: A\mathcal{A}A and RGraphRGraphRGraph. The data of an object in A\mathcal{A}A is a tuple (Ge,t,s)(G_e, t, s)(Ge​,t,s) where GeG_eGe​ is a set and t,s:Ge→Get,s: G_e \to G_et,s:Ge​→Ge​ are functions. Further, the conditions s∘t=ts \circ t = ts∘t=t and t∘s=st \circ s = st∘s=s must be satisfied. The goal, I think, is to create a reflexive graph from any such tuple.

The data of a reflexive graph, an object in RGraphRGraphRGraph, is a tuple (Ge,Gv,τ,σ,d)(G_e, G_v, \tau, \sigma, d)(Ge​,Gv​,τ,σ,d). Here GeG_eGe​ and GvG_vGv​ are I think sets, τ:Ge→Gv\tau: G_e \to G_vτ:Ge​→Gv​ tells us the target of an edge, and σ:Ge→Gv\sigma: G_e \to G_vσ:Ge​→Gv​ tells us the source of an edge, and d:Gv→Ged: G_v \to G_ed:Gv​→Ge​ assigns to each vertex the loop from that vertex to itself. That fact that, for each vertex vvv, the output d(v)d(v)d(v) of ddd is a loop from vvv to vvv is expressed by the condition that τ∘d=s∘d=1Gv\tau \circ d = s \circ d = 1_{G_v}τ∘d=s∘d=1Gv​​.

To make a reflexive graph from the data (Ge,t,s)(G_e, t, s)(Ge​,t,s), we need to come up with a set of vertices. To do this, we take the "joint equalizer" of the below diagram in Set\mathsf{Set}Set, which I assume is just the limit of this diagram:
diagram

I believe that the limit of this should be the subset of GeG_eGe​ containing elements eee so that s(e)=t(e)=es(e)=t(e)=es(e)=t(e)=e. So, our set of vertices GvG_vGv​ I think is the subset of elements eee from GeG_eGe​ satisfying s(e)=t(e)=es(e)=t(e)=es(e)=t(e)=e. Then we can define the function d:Gv→Ged: G_v \to G_ed:Gv​→Ge​ as the inclusion of these vertices into GeG_eGe​. (I think this is the key morphism that makes GvG_vGv​ a limit of this diagram).

We then want to determine a τ:Ge→Gv\tau: G_e \to G_vτ:Ge​→Gv​, which will be the "target" function for our reflexive graph. It is at this point that I get stuck! I think this is what the question above was asking about, as well. The book referenced in the screenshot says this:

This [joint equalizer diagram] yields the canonical factorizations τ:Ge→Gv\tau : G_e \to G_vτ:Ge​→Gv​ of ttt through ddd, and σ:Ge→Gv\sigma: G_e \to G_vσ:Ge​→Gv​ of sss though ddd (such factorizations exist because t=s∘t=t∘s∘t=t∘tt = s \circ t = t \circ s \circ t = t \circ tt=s∘t=t∘s∘t=t∘t and analogously for s).

But I don't follow what the author is saying here....

I think maybe the author is indicating there is a function τ\tauτ that makes this diagram commute:
factoring t through d

Ah, I think I get it! We use the universal property of a limit to get our τ\tauτ:
universal property

We need s∘t=ts \circ t =t s∘t=t and t∘t=tt \circ t = tt∘t=t for the "cone" with tip GeG_eGe​ to actually be a cone. But both of these are true equations, so this is a real cone, and so we can use this setup to uniquely specify τ\tauτ.

To specify σ\sigmaσ, I think one just has to use an analogous cone with tip GeG_eGe​ with "legs" made from sss instead of ttt.

Yes @Jan Pax , your question makes sense now. I'm sorry for making a comment on your English, but I didn't want your question to be ignored because it wasn't understood :sweat_smile:
Thanks for the thorough response @David Egolf
